comment.author: 73277077@N00
comment._content:
OK, last guess for today: the Yiddish sign at the back could well be calling for an eight-hour day. That would be the likeliest reason for a big number 8 on a strikers' placard in 1913.

Come on Yiddish and Italian speakers - we need you!

And a happy May Day 2009 to workers of all countries and languages!

comment.author: 18590655@N03
comment._content: The interesting thing about the Yiddish sign at the lower left is the adoption of English words. Looks to me like "Mir fordern yunion sheper un yunion kondishyons" (We demand union shops and union conditions). But the transliteration of "union" on a sign at a May Day rally suggests an amusing demand for immediate summer weather (June conditions).
